item.title: Romania’s Math Whiz President Faces Tough Budget Arithmetic
item.description: The ballot numbers added up for Romania’s Nicusor Dan, the one-time math prodigy who defeated a formidable far-right challenger to win the Black Sea nation’s presidency this month.
item.dc:creator: Irina Vilcu, Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Nicusor Dan Photographer: Alexandra Corcode/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Says He’s Eyeing Russia Sanctions, Calls Putin ‘Crazy’
item.description: President Donald Trump said he was “absolutely” considering new sanctions against Russia as Ukraine said Moscow launched its largest drone barrage of the war during a third night of strikes.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Rescue workers at the site of a Russian missile attack in Kyiv on May 25.

item.title: Trump’s Pivot Back to Tariffs Roils World Anew
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's prime minister, center, during the 46th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Monday, May 26, 2025. Southeast Asian leaders start two days of talks from Monday, seeking to deepen ties with China and Gulf nations, and mitigate the fallout from US President Donald Trump’s tariff hikes. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Finland Summons Russia’s Ambassador After Violation of Airspace
item.description: Finland summoned the Russian ambassador to provide an explanation for a recent suspected violation of airspace.
item.dc:creator: Kati Pohjanpalo

media:content.media:description: A Finnish Air Force F/A-18 Hornet pilot checks his aircraft wing during a NATO air force exercise in April. Photographer: John Thys/AFP/Gety Images

item.title: Israeli Military Aims to Take Over 75% of Gaza in Two Months
item.description: Israel aims to take control of 75% of the Gaza Strip and move its 2 million inhabitants into three designated areas as part of a new military offensive in the coastal strip.
item.dc:creator: Ian Fisher

media:content.media:description: The Israeli military conduct operations along the northern Gaza Strip border on May 20, 2025. Photographer: Mostafa Alkharouf/Anadolu/Getty Images

item.title: European Asset Managers Balk at Latest US Effort to Kill IRA
item.description: Inside one of Europe’s biggest asset managers, there’s growing concern that Republican efforts to gut legislation supporting key industries such as clean energy may result in the US losing its status as a destination for investor capital.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Marsh

item.title: India, Canada Hold Top-Level Talks to Mend Frayed Ties
item.description: Foreign ministers of Canada and India held a phone conversation on Sunday in their highest-level contact since Prime Minister Mark Carney took office, as both nations seek to repair strained ties.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Canada's Foreign Minister Anita Anand.

item.title: Japan’s Stocks Solid as Trump Rhetoric Cools; Nippon Steel Gains
item.description: Japanese shares gained for a second day on hopes of softer trade policies from US President Donald Trump, after he extended the deadline for higher duties on European Union goods and backed a deal between Nippon Steel Corp. and US Steel Corp.
item.dc:creator: Alice French, Toshiro Hasegawa

item.title: Xi Mulls New Made-in-China Plan Despite US Call to Rebalance
item.description: President Xi Jinping’s government is considering a new version of its master plan to boost production of high-end technological goods, according to people familiar with the matter, signaling its intention to keep a firm grip on manufacturing as President Donald Trump looks to bring more factories back to the US.
item.dc:creator: John Liu

media:content.media:description: Robotic arms operate on a production line at the Nio Inc. factory in China’s Anhui Province last April.

item.title: Multiple People Taken to Hospitals After Shooting Incident in South Carolina Beach Town
item.description: LITTLE RIVER, S.C. (AP) — At least 11 people were taken to hospitals after a shooting Sunday night in a South Carolina beach town, authorities said.

item.title: Macron Vows Closer Defense, Energy Ties in Visit to Vietnam
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron vowed closer cooperation on defense, transport and nuclear energy after talks with Vietnam’s leaders as he kicked off a tour of Southeast Asia aimed at shoring up alliances in the region.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Stevens, Nguyen Xuan Quynh, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron arrives at Noi Bai International Airport in Hanoi on May 25. Photographer: Ludovic Marin/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Optimistic on Iran Deal After ‘Very Good’ Rome Talks
item.description: US President Donald Trump said his administration’s talks with Iran over the weekend were “very good,” as he pushes to limit the Islamic Republic’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Maria Paula Mijares Torres

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks to members of the media before boarding Air Force One from Morristown Municipal Airport in Morristown, New Jersey, on May 25, 2025.

item.title: Japan to Sell Rice Stockpiles With Aim to Halve Soaring Prices
item.description: Japan will sell additional stockpiles of rice at a fixed price with an aim to halve soaring costs, newly-appointed agriculture minister Shinjiro Koizumi said as the country heads toward a summer election.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: A bag of packaged rice. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan Touts Ships Expertise, LNG Project as Tariff Talks Key
item.description: Japan may offer financial and technical contributions ranging from investment in an Alaskan LNG pipeline project to shipbuilding expertise as it seeks to smooth the path toward a tariff deal with the US by mid-June.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: Asean Must Keep Joining Global Supply Chains, Thailand Says
item.description: Southeast Asian nations should look at ways to further integrate their supply chains regionally and around the world to reap the benefits of economies of scale and gain access to larger markets, Thailand’s foreign minister said.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Maris Sangiampongsa Photographer: MANAN VATSYAYANA/AFP

item.title: Maduro Sweeps Venezuelan Regional Vote Marked by Low Turnout
item.description: Venezuela’s ruling party swept regional and parliamentary elections in a landslide Sunday, tightening President Nicolás Maduro’s grip on power after a low-turnout vote marred by widespread opposition abstention and international criticism.
item.dc:creator: Andreina Itriago, Patricia Laya

media:content.media:description: Nicolas Maduro in Caracas on May 22. Photographer: Jesus Vargas/Getty Images

item.title: Tusk Plan to Change Poland Turns on Knife-Edge Presidential Vote
item.description: Poland’s two presidential candidates are heading into the final week of a neck-and-neck election campaign that risks leaving Prime Minister Donald Tusk boxed in by a nationalist rival.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Bujnicki, Piotr Skolimowski

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski, his wife and Donald Tusk walk marching with supporters on May 25, 2025.

item.title: China’s Ambassador Warns Australia Over Port of Darwin Lease
item.description: China’s ambassador to Australia has warned Canberra to be careful in its handling of the lease of a strategically important port, after Prime Minister Anthony Albanese pledged to bring it back into his country’s hands.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: DARWIN, AUSTRALIA - APRIL 08: A general view of the access entry to the Port of Darwin on April 08, 2025 in Darwin, Australia. The lease of Darwin Port to China's Landbridge Group has become a contentious issue in the Australian federal election, with both major parties pledging to bring the port back under Australian ownership. Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has vowed immediate action to secure the port, citing national security concerns, while Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has emphasized ongoing efforts to find a private Australian buyer, framing the issue as critical to protecting Australia's strategic interests. (Photo by Darrian Traynor/Getty Images)

item.title: Malaysia’s Anwar Writes Trump Seeking Summit With Southeast Asia
item.description: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said he personally wrote to Donald Trump seeking to organize a meeting with Southeast Asian nations amid concerns over the US president’s proposed tariff hikes.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim Photographer: Prakash Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Extends Deadline for 50% Tariffs on EU Goods to July 9
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would extend the deadline for the European Union to face 50% tariffs until July 9 after a phone call with Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump walks to speak to members of the media before boarding Air Force One at Morristown Municipal Airport in Morristown, New Jersey, May 25, 2025.

item.title: Israel's Latest Strikes in Gaza Kill 38 People Including Children
item.description: DEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) — Israeli strikes over the past 24 hours killed at least 38 people in Gaza, including children, local health officials said Sunday, with no data available for a second straight day from now-inaccessible hospitals in the north.

media:content.media:description: People watch as smoke billows following an Israeli strike in Jabalia, in the northern Gaza Strip on May 25, 2025.

item.title: US Tariffs Loom Over Asia Summit as Ties With China Strengthen
item.description: Southeast Asian leaders start two days of talks from Monday, seeking to deepen ties with China and Gulf nations, and mitigate the fallout from US President Donald Trump’s tariff hikes.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry, Philip Heijmans, Netty Idayu Ismail

media:content.media:description: The logo of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is pictured in front of Malaysia's Petronas Twin Towers in Kuala Lumpur on May 15, 2025. (Photo by Mohd RASFAN / AFP) (Photo by MOHD RASFAN/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: MOHD RASFAN/AFP

item.title: Canada’s Liberals Decide Against New Rules to Oust Party Leader
item.description: Elected lawmakers in Canada’s governing Liberal Party voted against adopting a mechanism that would have given them more power to oust Prime Minister Mark Carney as party leader in the future.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Heinzl

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney Photographer: David Kawai/Bloomberg

item.title: Pope Leo XIV Prays for Chinese Catholics in First Comments on Thorny Issue
item.description: ROME (AP) — Pope Leo XIV asked Sunday for prayers for China’s Catholics to be in communion with the Holy See, as he made his first public remarks about one of the thorniest foreign policy issues facing his new pontificate.

media:content.media:description: Pope Leo XIV Photographer: ANDREAS SOLARO/AFP

item.title: Polish Presidential Hopefuls Rally Supporters Ahead of Vote
item.description: Supporters of Poland’s presidential contenders took to the streets of Warsaw on Sunday for parallel marches that highlight deep divisions in the European Union nation a week before a tightly-contested runoff election.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Ojewska, Piotr Bujnicki

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowsk speaks as he begins the Great Patriots’ March at Bankowy Square in Warsaw on May 25.

item.title: Prisoner Swaps Completed as Russia Fires Barrage at Kyiv
item.description: The third day of prisoner exchanges between Russia and Ukraine went ahead as planned on Sunday, wrapping up a program agreed to earlier this month, hours after a second night of deadly missile and drone strikes across much of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ros Krasny, Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: A high-rise residential building heavily damaged by a Russian drone strike in Kyiv on May 25. Photographer: Vitalii Nosach/Global Images Ukraine/Getty Images

item.title: Rayner Leaves Door Open on Benefit Reform as Farage Ups Pressure
item.description: UK Deputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner left the door open on whether the government will lift the two-child benefit cap even as Nigel Farage’s Reform UK seeks to outflank the ruling Labour Party in bringing down the cost of living.
item.dc:creator: Kit Rees

media:content.media:description: Britain's Deputy Prime Minister and Levelling Up, Housing and Communities Secretary Angela Rayner arrives at 10 Downing Street ahead of the meeting between Cyprus' President Nikos Christodoulides and Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer, in central London, on May 21, 2025. (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS / AFP) (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: German Finance Minister Urges Calm in US Tariff Fight, Bild Says
item.description: German Finance Minister Lars Klingbeil urged restraint in the escalating trade dispute between the European Union and the US in an interview with Bild am Sonntag.
item.dc:creator: Eva Brendel

media:content.media:description: Lars Klingbeil during a session at the Bundestag in Berlin, on May 15.

item.title: North Korea Detains Officials After Failed Warship Launch: KCNA
item.description: North Korea has detained key officials following a failed launch that damaged a destroyer, state media reported.
item.dc:creator: Yoolim Lee

media:content.media:description: CHONGJIN, NORTH KOREA -- MAY 23, 2025: 02 Maxar satellite imagery taken at 2:01 PM local time shows the aftermath of an accident at the Hambuk Shipyard during the launch of a new destroyer. The vessel is seen listing heavily and partially covered with blue tarps, indicating a potential failure during launch and efforts to conceal the extent of damage. Please use: Satellite image (c) 2025 Maxar Technologies.

item.title: Australia’s Opposition Parties on Track to Return to Coalition
item.description: Australia’s two center-right opposition parties appear to be on track to return to the Coalition, a longstanding alliance between the pair that suffered a surprise split last week in the wake of a disastrous election showing.
item.dc:creator: Michael Heath

media:content.media:description: CANBERRA, AUSTRALIA - SEPTEMBER 01: National Party leader David Littleproud attends a jobs and skills summit at Parliament House on September 1, 2022 in Canberra, Australia. The Australian government is bringing together political, business, union and community group leaders at Parliament House to address issues facing the Australian economy and workforce as inflation and interest rates continue to rise. (Photo by Martin Ollman/Getty Images)
